titlestmt.titleproper:
Irene Dubicka Morawska papers
1978-1987
CPAA 93-03 CPAA 93-03
titlestmt.subtitle: Finding Aid
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Finding aid prepared by Renata Vickrey and Ewa Wolynska

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2016-03-15T08:58-0400

did.unittitle: Irene Dubicka Morawska Papers
did.abstract: The collection consists of material related to activities of Mrs. Irene Dubicka-Morawska within organizations that supported Solidarity after the introduction to Martial Law in Poland on December 13, 1981. Mrs. Dubicka was also active within other Polish American organizations before 1981. The bulk of the material covers the years from 1981 till 1984. The support for Solidarity was wide spread and many organizations were established not only in the US but also in Western Europe and other countries. It was a tremendous effort among Polish Americans and recent Polish immigrants to create a network of support for the Solidarity movement and for people imprisoned by the communist government of Poland. The collection consists of documentation of the establishment of such organizations, and includes correspondence, reports on political and economic situations in Poland and the program of ongoing help for political prisoners.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Irene Dubicka, PhD (a.k.a. Mrs. Morawska, later Mrs. Christensen) - born in -USA in 1951, a psychologist, researcher, journalist, and translator; an active member of Polish-American organizations such as (delete PAC) STUDIUM; 1981-1982 Managing and Associate Editor of New Horizon (an English-language weekend edition and offshoot of the Nowy Dziennik, a.k.a. the Polish Daily News); after Dec.1981, worked with the Committee in Support of Solidarity, N.Y.; in Feb. 1982 established Solidarity International, Inc., in New York City; Jul. 1982 - Jan. 1983 served as a co-founder with Jerzy Milewski of--and international press officer for--the Coordinating Office Abroad of NSZZ "Solidarnosc" in Brussels, Belgium; and from 1986 working as an analyst at Sandia National Laboratories in Albuquerque, New Mexico.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents of the Collection
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of : private sociopolitical papers of Ms. Dubicka and her (now deceased) first husband Ted Morawski (IT manager/director at AIAA/IEEE/ABPI); records of Solidarity support organizations; statements pertaining to the political and economic situation in Poland after 1981 openly published by United States Government agencies and the United Nations, as well as other international human rights organizations; records related to STUDIUM (The North American Study Center for Polish Affairs), and the Polish American Congress (PAC). Memoirs of Jurek Przybylski, Solidarity activist; her masters' thesis from Columbia University on "Solidarity's Evolutionaries" (1984), and her chapter "Solidarity and Determination: Solidarity International, the Group of Delegates, and the Nationwide Resistance Committee (OKO)" (in "Poland's Solidarity Movement," eds. Lawrence Biondi and Franch Mocha; Loyola, 1984).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material in the collection is divided in 3 series:

list.item: Series I - Solidarity International and other Solidarity supporting groups
Series II - Underground publications related to Solidarity and situation in Poland

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Cite as: Irene Dubicka Morawska Papers (CPAA 93-03). Connecticut Polish American Archives, Central Connecticut State University, New Britain.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Collection was donated to the archives by Irene Dubicka Morawska in 1993.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: For related material see the following collections:

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Processed by Ewa Wolynska and Renata Vickrey.
